lg.l: Deep in the artist’s innermost heart
Was shrined a vision of loveliness rare:
Of waking life, and of dreamland a part;
A blending of all things fair.
And the pictured vision stirred in his soul,
Till forth he went on his mission to find
The full embodiment of the goal
Of beauty conceived in his mind.
He wandered along by the sea-beat shore—
Calm was the air, and calm was the sea;
Save the sad ocean dirge, that evermore
Sings the song of eternity.
He skirted the marge of many a bay;
He went by headlands, all craggy and bare:
Lovely the scenes that he met on his way;
But his visioned dream was not there.
Anon, the ocean puts forth its power;
And its crested waves, with thunder-roar,
Rush on the adamant cliffs that tower
High over the rock-bound shore.
But the artist’s vision was peace and calm—
Peace over the earth, and calm in the air—
So he turned from the ocean’s thunder-psalm;
For his ideal was not there.
He went to the mountain, whose snow-clad heads
Gleamed pure and cold, ‘gainst a sapphire sky;
He threaded the ravines, whose rocky beds
Were a tangle of greenery.
He passed through the forest arches, dim
With shade from the fronded canopy there;
He paused to listen to Nature’s hymn;
But the scene he sought was not there.
He came, at last, to a sylvan scene—
The artist’s heart gave a gladsome bound:
There, the embodiment, calm and serene,
Of his waking vision he found.
A settler’s home, with its broad, low cave,
And its trellissed porch, stood smiling there;
All in the calm of a summery eve—
Peace on earth and calm in the air.
The soft, green, velvety sward stretched round,
Where once the forest primæval did stand,
That forest still formed the furthermost bound
Of the scene, on every hand,
Save where a deep cleft in the sylvan scene
Gave a lightsome view of the broad champaign;
Showing dark forest, and meadow green,
Spread over the hill-foot plain.
Some woodland giants, all silver-hoar
From primal times, with the lichens grey,
Stretched mighty limbs o’er the cottage door,
Intercepting the sun’s bright ray.
And the streaming light of the evening sun
Glanced in and out of the frondage there—
Here a grey-green dun; there an amber glow
From the golden ambient air.
The myriad points of the leafy screen
Showed clear and sharp ‘gainst the daffodil sky;
While the curling smoke, from the cottage heath,
Slow wreathed through their tracery.
Over the lea, in the golden haze,
With their tinkling bells, come the lowing kine—
The busy housewife comes forth to gaze
At the homeward-winding line.
Two bright chubby children play at her knee—
Blue are their eyes, and fair is their hair—
While, by their dams, the lambs skip on the lea,
In the calm, soft evening air.
Then the artist traced that scene of rest,
With a living sense of its peaceful calm—
His satisfied soul in the work expressed
That rest is our nature’s balm—
For, “O give us peace,” and “O give us rest,”
Is ever our human psalm.
